bibl.note: This document is a letter written by Robert Chester to his daughter, Mary Jane Chester, on October 5, 1840. In the letter, Robert expresses his anxieties about Mary Jane's health, and has decided to have her aunt go to Columbia, Tennessee, to get her and bring her home. He also discusses a visit to his family by Andrew Jackson.

div1.p: We feel disposed to scold you for not writing — Only one letter in four weeks, and you have been Sick too — Mr Walkers last proved to be succeeded by a nother very soon, now ten days are passed & we have no letter
All this could be bourn, if we knew you were well, The great uncertainty of your silence on is what so much distresses us — Tomorrow is The last day we can wait, that mail must bring us a letter

I will give you, What I know will be agreeable intelligence to you — On next Friday your Aunt Narcissa starts to Columbia to see you & perhaps to bring you home, she would start to day but General Jackson reached here yesterday eveng, she wishes to stay with him untill after the 8 or the 9th. She will start, so you may expect her on Tuesday — 13th

We have to say, that as The session is so far advanced, that you do not comence school untill you hear again from us, indeed if the Chills continue to afflict you, you must
come home — We know you Can do no good at learning when you are shaking well the agree — Genl Jackson will return here by the way of Columbia, yr ma says you must not only see him, but get well acquainted with him — She says also that Cate Soften is to married on Thursday week to a Dr Jones from Middle Tennessee — You must cheer up Keep your spirits good dont be gloomy because you are a little Sick
Mr Brinkley will go up with your Aunt N — Your mother, Brother & Sister unite me in love to you — and beg you to turn all your kind friends our kind regards.

closer.add: Your ma says she hopes you have flannel & that you must not wear your clothes tight Your health is above all pride —
